channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2007 The New York Times Company

item.title: Shuttle Endeavour Lifts Off Toward Space Station
item.description: The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Fossils in Kenya Challenge Linear Evolution
item.description: Two fossils could rearrange major branches thought to be in a straight ancestral line to Homo sapiens.
item.author: JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

item.title: Aid to Help Asia and Africa With Effects of Warming
item.description: The Rockefeller Foundation says it will invest $70 million to help Asian cities and African farmers withstand floods, droughts and other global warming hazards.
item.author: ANDREW C. REVKIN

item.title: California: Stem Cell Program Appointment
item.description: California’s $3 billion stem cell research program appointed an interim president, Richard A. Murphy, while it continued a longer-than-expected search for a permanent chief.
item.author: ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: Ethanol Is Feeding Hot Market for Farmland
item.description: Skyrocketing farmland prices are stirring optimism, but for young and small-scale farmers, the news is grim.
item.author: MONICA DAVEY

item.title: The Energy Challenge: Cooking Up More Uses for the Leftovers of Biofuel Production
item.description: Scientists, entrepreneurs and venture capitalists are becoming increasingly interested in making more than fuel out of the raw materials for biodiesel fuel and ethanol.
item.author: HILLARY ROSNER

item.title: In Case of Apocalypse Later, a Plan to Ensure America’s Regreening
item.description: New York’s municipal native-plant nursery is part of a global project to collect and store seeds from 10 percent of the world’s flowering plant species in case of disaster.
item.author: ANDY NEWMAN

item.title: Warming Threatens Farms in India, U.N. Official Says
item.description: Climate change could ultimately affect food production and add to the woes of already desperate peasants in India, the official said.
item.author: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Beach Closings and Advisories
item.description: The number of United States beaches declared unsafe for swimming reached a record last year, the Natural Resources Defense Council reported.
item.author: REUTERS

item.title: Space Shuttle Set to Lift Off
item.description: The space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off on Wednesday night and head to the International Space Station.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Personal Health: Injections to Kick-Start Tissue Repair
item.description: Prolotherapy is an alternative medicine method to promote connective tissue repair even years after the damage occurred.
item.author: JANE E. BRODY

item.title: Vital Signs: Learning: In Tiny Part of the Brain, a Key to Foreign Tongues
item.description: A tiny part of the brain appears to play an important role in how well adults can learn another language, a new study finds.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Deadly Inheritance, Desperate Trade-Off
item.description: Some patients at high risk of pancreatic cancer opt for surgery that yields hope — and diabetes.
item.author: DENISE GRADY

item.title: In Dusty Archives, a Theory of Affluence
item.description: Gregory Clark believes that the Industrial Revolution occurred because of a change in the nature of the human population.
item.author: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Basics: Its Poor Reputation Aside, Our Fat Is Doing Us a Favor
item.description: Fat’s bland and amorphous appearance notwithstanding, it represents a highly specialized organ, as finely honed to the task of energy storage as muscle is built for flexing.
item.author: NATALIE ANGIER

item.title: Essay: What’s in a Name? Parsing the ‘God Particle,’ the Ultimate Metaphor
item.description: The biggest name-dropper in science, Albert Einstein, mentioned God often enough that one could imagine he and the “Old One” had a standing date for coffee or tennis.
item.author: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: From Fresh Ideas and Better Steel, Safer Bridges
item.description: Aging spans may be troubled, but more recent ones are longer and stronger thanks to new ideas and technologies.
item.author: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: The Consumer: It Banishes Uterine Fibroids, but for How Long?
item.description: Magnetic-resonance-guided focused ultrasound appeals to many women with fibroids but doubt about its efficacy remains.
item.author: RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Cases: In a Hospital Stay, No Time to Rest
item.description: Grand Central Terminal may be synonymous with noise and haste, but it can be a lot quieter than a hospital bed.
item.author: CAITLIN KELLY

item.title: Research Identifies Brain Site for Fever
item.description: New research indicates that the area of the brain responsible for causing fever would just about fit on the head of a pin.
item.author: AMANDA SCHAFFER

item.title: Doctors Warn Against Infrared Thermometers
item.description: Infrared thermometers have produced lower readings in lab tests meant to simulate athletic settings than other devices, which could deprive patients of critical care.
item.author: BARNABY J. FEDER

item.title: Kai Siegbahn, Swedish Physicist, Dies at 89
item.description: Dr. Siegbahn’s work in developing a novel technique using electrons to test the composition and purity of materials received a Nobel Prize in 1981.
item.author: JEREMY PEARCE

item.title: Teacher-Astronaut to Fly Decades After Challenger
item.description: Barbara R. Morgan, a former teacher, is about to fulfill a two-decade-old dream by becoming the first “educator astronaut.”
item.author: WARREN E. LEARY

item.title: Observatory: Ancient Flying Reptiles Probably Swooped, Not Skimmed, for Food
item.description: A new report suggests that pterosaurs probably were incapable of skimming behavior.
item.author: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Q & A: Little Blue Lights
item.description: Is it true that airport taxiways are lined with blue lights because blue light can be seen from the longest distance?
item.author: C. CLAIBORNE RAY

item.title: Judge Limits Navy Sonar, Citing a Threat to Wildlife
item.description: A federal judge ordered the Navy to stop using medium-range sonar in training exercises, citing a prediction that marine mammals could be harmed.
item.author: FELICITY BARRINGER

item.title: Observatory: A New Answer for Another Mystery in Saturn’s Rings
item.description: The latest puzzle to be cleared up about Saturn’s rings involves the origin of one of the outermost ones, a thin, faint one labeled G.
item.author: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Observatory: Found at Yellowstone: Hot Spring Bacteria That Harvest Light
item.description: Yellowstone is home to elk and bison, wolf and beaver, eagle and hawk — and a newly discovered light-harvesting bacterium.
item.author: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Really?: The Claim: With Sunscreens, High SPF Ratings Are Best
item.description: Everyone knows that an SPF rating of 60 provides double the protection of SPF 30 — or does it?
item.author: ANAHAD O’CONNOR

item.title: Vital Signs: Aging: Hip Protectors Don’t Help Prevent Fractures in Falls
item.description: A new study raises questions about the effectiveness of padded hip protectors worn by older people to help prevent fractures if they fall.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Vital Signs: Mental Abilities: Good Readers Better Able to Retain Brain Skills
item.description: Years of reading, a new study suggest, may help a brain develop more of what doctors call cognitive reserve.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Vital Signs: Awareness: Counseling by Phone Benefits Drinkers
item.description: A new study has found that counseling by telephone could be effective in curbing excessive drinking.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: In a Former First Family, Cancer Has a Grim Legacy
item.description: Few families have been as devastated by pancreatic cancer as that of former President Jimmy Carter.
item.author: DENISE GRADY

item.title: News Reports Are Criticized by Astronaut
item.description: The commander of the space shuttle mission scheduled to be launched on Tuesday sent a letter saying that reports of alcohol use by astronauts had been exaggerated.
item.author: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Astronaut Profiles
item.description: Profiles of the seven members of STS-118, which will bring structural elements up to the International Space Station and carry on the process of building the station.
item.author: JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: Setback for Novartis in India Over Drug Patent
item.description: Drug companies can continue to make less expensive generic drugs, many of which flow to the developing world, after an Indian court Monday rejected a patent law challenge.
item.author: AMELIA GENTLEMAN
